description: American writer and entrepreneur, and creative director. Omar Spahi has worked in comic books since 2011. The creator of Xenoglyphs and the upcoming title Thaniel, Omar now runs his own toy and publishing company (OSSM Comics). He is currently producing an animated series and app game for Xenoglyphs.
name: Omar Spahi

description: Filipino penciller, inker, and colorist. PJ Catacutan has worked in the fields of art, design, advertising, and comic books since he was a boy. He is currently working on Xenoglyphs.
name: P. J. Catacutan

deck: Accomplished graphic artist. Also known as "Maza."
name: Milorad Vicanovic

deck: Chris Dickens is a comic book writer, creator, and the founder of Lionheart Comics.
description: Chris Dickens is a comic book writer, creator, and the founder of Lionheart Comics. Mr. Dickens was born and raised in Southern California. He was a regular in his high school theater productions, and a writer for the school paper. After joining the Army at 17, Chris studied Creative Writing at Colorado Mesa University (CMU) in Grand Junction, CO. Chris now lives in Orange County with his wife and three children.
name: Chris Dickens

deck: Phil Morgenthaler is one half of Yvette Avenue Productions.
name: Phil Morgenthaler

deck: Jason Pell is an acclaimed graphic novelist largely recognized for his work on Zombie Highway, Woody and the Noble, Ghost Telling, and Season's End. His writing also appears in Chillers Vol #1 and Vol #2, and has a short story in Strange Critters. On October 2, 2013, Jason's  Kickstarter campaign for his newest book: Suicide 5- A Tale That Ends In Death was successfully funded.
name: Jason Pell

deck: Jonathan Baylis is a former Marvel, Valiant, and Topps Comics intern turned independent writer. He parted from Marvel and went on to produce his own autobiographical comic entitled So Buttons.  The book has sold moderately well and was featured on the AMC television series Comic Book Men.
name: Jonathan Baylis

deck: She did lettering on the Survivors books. Spouse of Steve Woron, I believe.
name: Darla Woron

deck: Original Dandy editor, whose chin was used as the inspiration for the chin on Desperate Dan.
description: Editor of the Dandy from its launch in 1937 until his retirement in 1982, except for the years 1940 through 1946, when he was serving in the Royal Navy during and immediately after World War II. Co-creator of Desperate Dan with Dudley D. Watkins, and writer of the strip in the first few years.
name: Albert Barnes

description:
Born in Santpoort, a small town near Haarlem in the Netherlands, Bert Bus began his art career soon after the end of World War II when he took up a job with publisher De Spaarnestad. He would remain with that company his entire career, initially working on womenâ€™s magazine Libelle. After a brief break to do national service between 1950 and 1952, Bus resumed working for De Spaarnestad, with his first comic work on the SF series Olaf Noord from 1953 until 1956, initially published in Rebellenclub and later in Sjors after that title merged with Rebellenclub. Bus also drew the humour strip Skokan (about a young caveboy) between 1955 and 1956, historical adventure series Theban, de Eerste Wereldreiziger (Theban, the first world traveller) from 1956 until 1959. Overlapping this period, Bert tried his hand at writing, producing Woep en Wap for the womenâ€™s magazine Rosita between 1958 and 1967. From 1959 Sjors was revamped, and Bert Bus took up art chores on three series in swift succession, De Brug in het Oerwoud (The Bridge in the Jungle, 1960-1961), De Gouden Kraag (The Golden Collar, 1962) and De Slavenkoopman van PompeÃ¯ (The Slave Merchant of Pompei, 1963), before moving to the SF series De Avonturen van Cliff Rendall (The Adventures of Cliff Rendall, 1963-1965) and Lance Barton, while also adapting Huckleberry Finn. In 1969 he drew Nancy Drew and then in 1970 Jola, both for Tina, a girlsâ€™ comic which was otherwise purely reprint material. Back in Sjors, reprint material had run out for the British strip Robot Archie (Archie, de Man van Staal, as he was called in the Netherlands), and Bert began producing new strips, initially based on the scripts of already printed stories, and later brand new strips with Bert covering writing as well as art.

During this period De Spaarnestad merged with fellow publisher De GeÃ¯llustreerde Pers, with the combined company taking on the name Oberon. Sjors then merged with Pep and changed its name to Eppo, and Bert began working on new series Stef Ardoba (1975-1982) and then Malorix (1983-1985), before finishing his full time career with the Russ Bender series. He retired in 1989, but remained active on the European comic convention scene, and in 2004 he and fellow creators Harry Balm and Nico van Dam were awarded the Bulletje and Boonestaakschaal for contributions to Dutch comics.
name: Bert Bus

description:
Lindsay Walker is a comic book artist that has worked published on The Phantom, Zombies Vs Cheerleaders, Kolchak/Sherlock Holmes, Street Fighter, Darkstalkers and Voltron. Her first creator owned comic 'Tales from Half-World: White-Head made and Cursed was published in SeqaPUNCH! #1.

She unfortunately passed away on September 30, 2016 at the age of 37 (Suicide).
name: Lindsay C Walker

deck: Writer of mystery novels, most notably the Southern Vampire series which was optioned by Alan Ball for an HBO series that was then optioned by IDW for comic adaptations.
description:
In 1981 Charlaine Harris's first novel Sweet & Deadly, was published, followed in 1984 by A Secret Rage. The reception of these two stand-alone, southern based mystery novels was mediocre and the books quickly went out of print. Life for Ms. Harris (who goes by her married name in real life) continues, as life will, but she kept writing while raising her children.

Then, in 1990 her first Aurora Teagarden mystery, Real Murders was published as a cozy and sold well. Real Murders was followed by 8 other Aurora Teagarden mysteries.

By the time she was finished with that series, Ms. Harris had started another southern-based cozy mystery starring Lily Bard and set in Shakespeare Arkansas. There were five books in that series and Lily and Jack make a cameo appearance in one of the Sookie Stackhouse/Southern Vampire books.

In 2001 Dead Until Dark was released at the advent of the new paranormal romance rage of the early 2000s through the present. The tales of Sookie Stackhouse, telepathic cocktail waitress and her shape-shifting boss, Sam Merlotte, her boyfriend, Vampire Bill and later Shreveport vampire bar owner, Eric Northman was a hit. Alan Ball optioned the series for adaptation into an HBO series which has been quite profitable for Ms. Harris despite the fact that very early on in the show the characters deviated wildly from their "origins" in her novels and the addition of several characters created wholly by Alan Ball (Jessica). IDW optioned the HBO series for graphic novel expansion/adaptation.

In 2005 Grave Sight was published to start a series of 4 novels featuring Harper Connelly and Tolliver Lang. The series came to a conclusion with book 4, An Ice Cold Grave. Book one, Grave Sight, was adapted into graphic-novel format quite poorly; there are no announced plans to adapt the other 3 novels.

With all 4 of her series wrapped up, Ms. Harris has a new graphic-novel co-written with Christopher Golden: Cemetery Girl, due to start in January 2014 as graphic novel, not individual issues.
name: Charlaine Harris

deck: Writer of the critically acclaimed Titan: An Alternate History, released by AH Comics in 2011.
name: Michael Tymczyszyn

deck: Co-writer & co-creator of the recently released End Times Of Bram & Ben miniseries from Image Comics.
name: Jim Festante
